summary: This document is a sealed application by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York for a non-disclosure order related to a grand jury subpoena issued to Iterative Capital / Iterative OTC LLC. The subpoena seeks arbitration materials related to a fraudulent cryptocurrency scheme involving J. Barry Thompson and Volantis entities, which is under investigation for wire fraud conspiracy. The application argues that disclosure would jeopardize the investigation by alerting the targets, who might flee or destroy evidence.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Signs the grand jury subpoena and the cover letter as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Robert H. Hotz Jr.
persons.context: Listed as the attorney for Iterative Capital / Iterative OTC LLC at Akin Gump LLP, to whom the subpoena and correspondence are addressed.

persons.name: Drew Skinner
persons.context: The attorney who submits the affirmation and application for the non-disclosure order on behalf of the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: J. Barry Thompson
persons.context: Identified as a key target in the investigation of a fraudulent scheme to obtain millions of dollars from Iterative and another entity by promising cryptocurrency in exchange for fiat currency.

persons.name: Sarah Netburn
persons.context: Issues the final Non-Disclosure Order pursuant to the All Writs Act.

connections.description: Thompson and/or associates allegedly defrauded Iterative by obtaining millions of dollars with a promise to provide cryptocurrency that was never delivered.
Hotz is the attorney representing Iterative, as indicated by the subpoena being addressed to him on behalf of the company.
Skinner is an Assistant United States Attorney working in the office of U.S. Attorney Geoffrey S. Berman.

events.title: Fraudulent Transaction with Iterative
events.description: Target Subjects, including J. Barry Thompson, obtained millions of dollars from Iterative by promising cryptocurrency in exchange for fiat currency but failed to deliver.

events.title: Similar Fraudulent Transaction
events.description: Target Subjects obtained millions of dollars from another unnamed entity in a similar fraudulent cryptocurrency scheme.

events.title: Arbitration Proceeding Initiated
events.description: Iterative entered into an arbitration proceeding against Volantis entities related to the June 2018 transaction.

events.title: Arbitrator Decision for Iterative
events.description: The arbitrator issued a decision in Iterative's favor in its arbitration against Volantis.

events.title: Grand Jury Subpoena and Non-Disclosure Application
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office issues a grand jury subpoena to Iterative and files a sealed application for a non-disclosure order to prevent Iterative from notifying the investigation targets.

events.title: Scheduled Grand Jury Appearance
events.description: Iterative is commanded to appear before the Grand Jury, though personal appearance is waived if records are produced by the return date.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, Room 220, New York, New York
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office is conducting a criminal investigation into a fraudulent cryptocurrency scheme involving J. Barry Thompson and Volantis entities, suspected of violating wire fraud and conspiracy statutes (18 U.S.C. §§ 1343 and 1349).
The investigation focuses on transactions in June and July 2018 where victims, including Iterative Capital, paid millions in fiat currency for promised cryptocurrency that was never delivered.

A sealed non-disclosure order was granted, prohibiting Iterative from notifying anyone (including the investigation targets) about the grand jury subpoena for one year, to prevent flight, evidence tampering, or jeopardizing the investigation.
The subpoena specifically seeks all discovery, transcripts, and documents from Iterative's arbitration proceeding against Volantis, which Iterative won in November 2018.

The government argues the targets have substantial financial means in cryptocurrency, facilitating potential flight, and that evidence is largely digital and easily destroyed if the investigation is revealed.
